title: The Futurists - EPS_295: Hollywoodâ€™s AI Future with Doug Shapiro

rawLines.text: This week on the futurists, Doug
Shapiro. Derivative will be
commoditized. Derivative is what
generative AI is excellent at is making
things that are something like something
else. And so what will be more scarce
and more valuable is truly original,
compelling
[Music]
stories. Hey there, welcome back to the
futurist. I'm Rob Tersik and this week
I'm flying solo as my colleague Brett
King is traveling as he tends to do and
when he travels it gives me a chance to
catch up with people that are on my list
that I've wanted to talk to for a mighty
long time and today we're going to have
a conversation with someone I've wanted
to have on this show for more than a
year. I'm so thrilled to have Doug
Shapiro join us. Doug is a prolific
Substacker, one of my favorite
newsletters to read because it's a topic
that I care deeply about, which is the
future of media and
entertainment. And that world is going
through traumatic change right now. But
I suspect what's on the other side of
that change is going to be abundance and
some good fun. So without further ado,
welcome Doug. It's great to have you on
the futures. Thanks for joining us
today. Thank you. Thank you for having
me on. Doug, you've been in this space
for mighty long time. I know you were an
executive at Time Warner where you were
doing uh you were doing you're an
analyst so you were focused on like what
comes next and helping do strategic
planning but then you set off on your
own. So tell me a little bit about your
trajectory since then and how you became
a prolific substacker and one of the
leading thinkers about the future of
media. Uh well I don't know where you
got that line from. I guess you've been
I made it up. Yeah my show that told you
that one. Um well I I'll go back a
little further. So I've been in and
around media for 30 years. I was an
analyst covering on Wall Street covering
media stocks for you know roughly 14
years and then I went to Time Warner. I
was there for 12 years. I ran investor
relations. Uh I did some strategy roles.
My last role was running strategy for
Turner. And so when I left um I did a
couple things. Uh took a spatical for a
year took uh took a try at a spa which
was uh a good learning experience. Yeah.
uh a fail back. Um but you know really
the the reason I started writing was to
um uh replicate what I had as an analyst
which is I you know I learned early on
kind of accidentally that writing is
just a great forcing function for
learning. Um you know I I don't know if
you get the sense when I write but I'm
not writing to convey what I know. I I
start out with a question and then I use
the writing process to try to wrestle an
answer to the ground. Um and uh and also
on Wall Street you have a really taught
feedback mechanism because there's a lot
of money at stake. So you write a report
and you get yelled at or people love it
or whatever. The stock goes up, stock
goes down. And so um you know I said
well how do I replicate that kind of
forced learning and feedback mechanism?
And I'm like, "Wow, there's this thing
called the internet and it's a
relatively new phenomenon that you can
just put your ideas out into the world."
And uh so that was the that was really
the genesis of it. Nothing more than
that. And what has the response been? Is
it generally positive or do you have
your share of critics? Uh there's
definitely critics. I mean that's that
kind of goes with the territory. I'd say
um you know I I gauge the the worst
thing that can happen is indifference.
Uh, so I I gauge the response by, you
know, just levels of engagement and um,
yeah, vitrial is good. It's a sign of
high engagement, right? Exactly.
Exactly. Yeah. I mean, you know, if
people if people are yelling at me, then
that that at least means they're paying
attention. But um, you know, I think
generally people are supportive. What
I'm trying to do, which I I think is
different, is really look at the
fundamental structural changes that are
underway. There's a lot of noise in
media as you know and there are a lot of
people dissecting what happened
yesterday and this earnings report and
that's that earnings report. Um, and my
view is that if you really understand
what's happening on a on a fundamental
level, on a kind of a first principles
level, then that helps you um a kind of
at least like determine a um the
probability distribution of how the
world might evolve. Um, but it also is a
really useful tool for filtering the all
the noise, right? because you have at
least a context with which to to
interpret new information. It's a really
important point because you know on this
show one of the things we want to do is
help our listeners develop a better
understanding of the future and the
forces that shape the future effectively
to think more effectively about the
future. And uh one of the things I run
into persistently is um uh particularly
if I'm working on client work where
people want my advice or they want my
perspective about the future, I always
start with long-term trends and I take a
look at history, especially the history
leading up to how we got to the moment
we're in. Um that's not necessarily a
foolproof way of of forecasting, but at
least it shows you the context within
which these changes are occurring. And
there's really two things for media that
I think really are are quite important
if we want to talk about the future. The
first one is the trends. Of course, you
have lots to say on that subject. Um,
and then secondly, the value control
points. Uh, the media industry has
always been controlled by value control
points. Large media companies are large
because they control several value
control points, you know, in the media
supply chain. Everything from financing
to access to stars to access to IP and
the, you know, the resources to produce,
the re the ways to distribute a market.
Um, however, the trends are shifting
those uh value control points or they're
shifting value away from those points to
other points. And this is where I find
so much value in the work that you're
doing, in the writing that you're doing
because uh an astute reader can read
your your newsletter and start to see
what direction value is shifting towards
and then you can start to see those as
opportunities to find a new value
control point, maybe sees it and that's
a way to build a new business or to
generate profit in the future. Uh for
those who are listening, if this sounds
interesting to you, I I can tell you
that the newsletters are brilliantly
written. They're succinct, yet they're
packed full of information. Uh the
newsletter is called The Mediator. It's
on Substack and it's by Doug Shapiro.
And that should be enough information
for you to find it. Okay. So Doug, uh
give me the big picture. What's
happening right now in the media
landscape? Uh give me a couple bullet
points and then we'll drill deeper.
Uh well the one sentence summary that I
use is that the last 15 to 20 years in
media were were really defined by the
disruption of of content distribution
and that the next decade plus is going
to be defined by the disruption of
content creation. So that's the one
sentence version. Mhm. I think if you go
back um what you'd say is that there
were really two
foundational technological changes that
happened starting well I mean really
starting kind of in the ' 40s50s you
know but implemented in the kind of '
80s '90s through the early 2000s which
was one was digitization and the other
one was the internet and and what
digitization did was it broke down the
silos in media because it used to be
that you know all media had a different
you know atomic unit. Um, right. Like
the what's the what's the disc or a disc
like a note or a you know a note in
music or a frame or in a in a in in a
photograph or video or whatever. And
what digitization did was it made the
atomic unit of all media the bit, right?
And then what the internet did was it
unified all those bits on one network.
So instead of having all these you know
modality or format specific distribution
network supply chains you basically had
one you had one network more or less one
form factor. And so what that did is it
um it really changed the architecture of
media. It changed the way first
digitization converted all media to bits
and the internet changed how those bits
move around. And so what that did um you
know it did a bunch of things but the
the critical thing it did is that it it
changed the cost of media distribution
from really expensive to it put it on a
path to be functionally free and the
reason is is because the internet
unbundled the information from the
infrastructure. It used to be that you
need to own this really expensive
underlying infrastructure whether that
was a broadcast antenna or hybrid fiber
coax cable or or you know a a very
specialized newspaper supply chain or
whatever it is. You didn't need to own
any of that anymore to be in the media
distribution business. And so you can
trace that one can go to Substack and
publish a newsletter for instance.
Exactly. you know, where does Netflix
come, you know, Axios and and and
Spotify and every, you know, most of
what we talk about today in media,
everything that's really emerged in the
last, you know, 20 some odd years have
all essentially ridden, they're all
riding on infrastructure that somebody
else paid for. So, you have that
foundational change of the cost of bits
going from really expensive to on a on a
path to be functionally free. And that
led to what I call the tectonic
uh trends in that exist in media today.
the kind of low background hum of
operating in the business which is
number one you have deflation price
deflation right there's a lot of pricing
pressure you have um stagnation of time
spent um a third one is you have
fragmentation of attention
um and a fourth one is disintermediation
of traditional intermediaries which is
what you were just kind of referring to
and then the fifth one is what I call
concentration concentration of power in
a few platforms and attention in a
handful of hits. So that's a lot and we
could unpack any of those you want to,
but um yeah, that that's pretty much the
agenda for the show there. Yeah. Yeah.
Yeah. So, so I think that you know the
that you know again just to draw the
thread here you these foundational
technological changes, general purpose
technologies, incredibly broad
implications across the economy. This is
what they do to media. This is the state
of media today.
And most of what we talk about in media
today is a lagging indicator of that
last disruption. Right? All of those
trends are a lagging indicator of what
happened
over the last, you know, plus years. And
there's another
and there's another disruption coming.
And that's the disruption in in the cost
of content creation. So that's the kind
of full, you know, that's the that's the
outline of the full picture and happy to
go anywhere. Well, you just framed the
whole conversation. So let me let me
recap, but let me let me spin it back uh
for those who are listening. So Doug
just talked about five factors that have
completely revised the way we distribute
the way we package, distribute, and sell
content and thereby tremendous number of
consequences for the media industry and
the companies that produce it. Uh we're
going to cover that. We're going to go
back to each of those five points in a
second. But then Doug just pointed to um
another major trend that we're just at
the very beginning of which is the
advent of uh automation of the creative
process and that's code for AI. The
topic that keeps coming up on the show
week after week after week. We can't
seem to avoid it because it's
everywhere. But in the media business
actually has some pretty profound
implications. So we'll cover the AI part
in the second half. But first let's just
get into and unpack those five points.
Um the first one you talked about is
price deflation and that's a big one
because uh you know when I was coming up
in the media business cable TV was
coming up at the same time and that's
where I started and uh there was a very
clear hierarchy when I got to when I
came to Hollywood and joined a movie
studio at the top of the pyramid was the
motion picture business the movie
company that was the prestige department
those people had all the stars and all
the money then there was the TV people
and they were the second you know in
line or you know the next ones down the
rung
And then there was cable which was kind
of like the bargain basement of
television. Uh no one got any respect
for working in cable though we made all
the money for the rest of the company.
And then I was in the internet
department which was like really the
subb if you will. And I went from that
subb and mobile at the time was was
hopelessly degraded as far as the media
business was concerned. But even then in
the 90s I was quite it was quite clear
to me because I was looking at the
number of units. Yeah, I worked at Sony
Pictures, so I was a leazison to Sony
Sony hardware and and uh I saw the
number of units we were selling in
mobile phones even in the '90s. And I
was like, well, it's just a matter of
time before billions of people have
these things and it's going to invert
that whole power pyramid. And here we
are today, and that's absolutely the
case where, you know, the the motion
picture company, there's no prestige in
the movie business anymore. It's in
tatters. Uh they are uh you know, all
movie chains are bankrupt right now. the
the theatrical experience is in
disarray. Uh even the prestige talent is
migrating to streaming because that's
where they can tell a 26-hour show
instead of a two-hour show, which is for
a writer or director or actor a way
better showcase of their talent. And um
and and all of those money makers, you
know, the blockbuster films, the uh the
broadcast networks, uh and and
particularly cable, which was the
biggest driver of revenue and profit for
Time Warner when you were there. All of
that now is in tatters. All of that is
in disarray. So, so talk to me about
price deflation and then the
consequences of that for the media
business.
Yeah. And what I'm referring to is not
new at all, right? Uh I worked with with
Jeff Zucker for a while uh at at Time
Warner and in 2008 when he was running
uh NBCU he had this famous line that he
warned the big media companies not to
trade analog dollars for digital dimes.
So that was that was 17 years ago when
he warned that. I think that what's a
little surprising is how persistent it
is. And so I I recently wrote a piece
about this about price deflation in
media. And what I showed is that if you
look at um if if you look at
monetization per hour, you see that
linear TV is still monetizing, you know,
50% higher than Netflix per hour, and
it's like three times as much as YouTube
per hour. Uh in gaming, you see the same
thing with console gaming. It's still
monetizing much higher than PC or
mobile. And in music, um, if you think
about what people used to spend per
minute of consumption when they bought a
CD versus what they're spending now per
minute or per hour of consumption on
Spotify, it's it's probably like 10x.
And so I think that what's surprising
is, you know, like let's take TV as an
example. Netflix has been raising prices
for years. Um, I think some would say
relatively aggressively. And yet still
that gap persists. So I think that what
is you know in some ways if you just
think about it from like an ecom 101
standpoint you'd say the barriers to
distribute fell there's more content
there's more supply prices go down and
that's you know I think a relatively
that is what what's happened I think
that what's surprising is that you know
we're 20 years into this disruption and
it persists
back in uh back in the late 90s John
Malone the you know kind of the the
godfather of the cable business cable
cowboy yeah Yeah. He said to me
um he said the cable TV business model
is the greatest mechanism ever invented
or ever devised for profit maximization
in media. And and that is a really great
succinct statement. And what you had was
two two groups that didn't necessarily
like each other or get along but they
had a perfect alignment of interests. Uh
the the channel providers and then the
cable distributors. And because it was
private infrastructure uh and and and
essentially monopolistic in nature, they
were able to extract monopoly pricing.
They were able to extract monopoly rent.
And anyone who was around at that time
remembers how much people hated their
cable company, particularly TCI, which
gave the worst service and charged the
highest prices. Yeah. Um so that did
really well at the time, but it only
worked because it was a closed system.
And so the the opening up, you know, not
just uh not just YouTube, but generally
the opening up that you described with
the internet destroyed monopoly pricing
control. And so that's one of the
reasons why we've seen the deflation.
That's one of the reasons why YouTube
doesn't monetize at the level of
broadcast TV. What that also points to
is that there's a lot of life left yet
in television, both in pay TV,
satellite, cable, and in broadcast.
These business are not dead. Uh they're
not growing, but they're coming down
from such a great height. there's plenty
of money there for a long time. Uh you
probably wouldn't go into that if you
were 22 years old because it's not a
growth industry. But uh you I don't
think I don't think you can say that
those are dead and done. I say that
because often I see stuff on uh LinkedIn
or on uh Instagram where people say,
"Oh, it's over. Hollywood's finished.
The mood the TV business is done." Those
people are ignorant. That's just not
true. Uh and by the way, I I don't think
any of this stuff is going to
destabilize Hollywood in the in the way
people in the way popular imagination
thinks it will happen. Okay, let's go on
to the next one. So, you talked about
stagnation of time. Maybe just to follow
up on that, right? Yeah, I agree with
all that. I think just to
maybe um bring it home a little bit for
me, I think there's a couple of
implications of this deflation um that
are that are worth pointing out. One is
that uh when you see disruption, it it
often shifts value to consumers, right?
when you when you you know when you
think about like you know the if prices
are lower what that means that consumers
are getting more for their money right
so if you think about a value chain that
includes consumers you'd say value has
shifted to consumers right um and uh I
I'm trying to remember what the otheram
what the other point well I mean the
example there is let's just take
streaming right so the crazy streaming
war we've seen for the last 10 years um
billions have been spent on programming
that you can't possibly consume, right?
No one can watch all the stuff that's
available on Netflix, Disney Plus, Max,
etc., etc., etc. Uh, so in a way that's
a wasted, you know, that's an
inefficient spend. But on the other end,
like you said, at the end of the value
chain is the consumer. That's an
unbelievable bounty of content. We we
have this content abundance and it's
quite good. Like the most of the quality
of the content is quite good. Yeah. Not
it's not very time efficient. You know,
you have to spend 10 hours to figure out
what the show's even about. But if
you're entertained by it. Yeah. So value
has shifted to consumers. I think the
other the other point I was going to
make is that
um because of this price pressure,
there's just less money in the system.
And I think that that when you think
about the problems in Hollywood, you
know, why um production spend is coming
down and uh why morale is so bad and why
RSN's are, you know, going bankrupt and
why, you know, there's controversy over
the the you know, the theatrical window
or why are Scout Johansson sued Disney
because of the way Black Widow was
distributed or, you know, whatever any
of those things. um they're really all
occurring because there's now less money
in the system than there used to be and
you know there which means there's less
money for everyone seated at the table
and that's a very so so to your point
earlier I agree with you there's still a
lot of money in legacy media and and uh
I did an analysis that if you look at
the total video pie in in the United
States which is all linear and streaming
and and theatrical and home video 66 6
cents of the dollar is still linear TV.
Yeah, that's true. Streaming doesn't
monetize at the level that any of those
previous mediums media did. Exactly. But
it's also pretty
wrenching when when anything goes X
growth, when things start to shrink, it
becomes very wrenching to the system.
And so, yeah, there's a lot of money
that's still there, but it becomes um
it's very hard to go from it's very hard
to go down, you know, it's very hard.
No, we can put a we can put a real clear
case on it. So, you know, if you know
folks who are writers who worked in
television, uh when we were young men
starting our careers, there were
showrunners who made generational wealth
with a successful show that they would
be able to pass on to their family for
the next three generations. Today,
that's simply impossible. that would not
occur. Uh cable started, you know, with
cable the shows were total buyout. So
you got paid producer fees, but you
didn't get any backend, any kind of
royalties. So if you made a hit show,
sayanara sucker, maybe we'll see on the
renewal, but otherwise you're not going
to be getting any huge residuals or
royalties. Streaming, you know, there
they just put this blunt force mechanism
in place of capsu uh and bonuses, you
know, but no kind of royalties. So if
the show performs, yeah, maybe you get a
second check, that's nice, but you're
not going to retire on that. So, the um
the shrinking of revenue has directly
impacted the creative people who produce
it. And now, I'm sure there's folks
listening thinking like, "Oh, really?
I'm supposed to feel sorry for some
screenwriter who lives in Malibu." Um,
but it's worth pointing out that there
are some 400,000 people here in Los
Angeles who are indirectly or directly
in engaged in the motion picture
business. And so, as that industry
shrinks and as the salaries go down, uh,
actually does it does change lifestyles
for people. And the typical screenwriter
gets paid you not a glorious wage, but
if they're fortunate, they're going to
earn $150,000 a year. So these changes
do have an impact and they hurt. Yeah.
And that's what I think that's what you
saw on the strikes that the you know
what what really what really this you
know the the the writers and the actors
were really um you know they were they
were really striking
against disruption. They were compress
economic. Yeah. shrinking the writer
room, which means each writer has to
work more. Again, you know, it's pretty
hard to feel sympathy for a latte
sipping uh writer in a writer's room,
but it actually does impact their lives.
I mean, they end up having to do more
work. So, okay, let's let's cover the
other four. Um otherwise, we're going to
burn the whole show on this topic,
though. Obviously, we could go a long
time. So yeah, you talked about the
stagnation of time, which is really the
time spent with media and and what you
mean by that is everybody's got a
limited amount of time they can spend on
entertainment and now we have a lot more
choices. Uh so so I guess tell me about
what you mean there. Yeah, that is
that's pretty straightforward. It just
um u if you look at time spent with
media, at least in the United States
right now, the average US adult spends
about 75% of of waking hours with media.
Um and that isn't you know again there's
like it gets like a little bit hard to
measure because there's this question of
multitasking and and double counting and
all that but um most of our waking day
and um it's not really growing anymore.
It grew with the advent of mobile in
2008 and then it sort of leveled off and
then we had a co bump and then since
then it has not grown at all. So there's
just only so many hours in the day.
Yeah. And um ultimately that's just a
structural constraint on the the growth
of media revenue because media
ultimately is about the monetization of
attention and engagement. There's just
not a lot of attention to go around.
That's right. Okay. So that one
dovetales neatly with the next one which
is the fragmentation of attention across
devices. So that you know in the
meantime while these last 30 years we've
been talking about the changes in the
media business. Um, this notion that you
go sit down at 8:00 in front of the
television in the living room, that idea
is out the window. That's been dead and
done for quite some time. Now we get
media all the time on the device of our
choice. Um, you know, we're standing in
line at the grocery store. There's
enough time to watch two Tik Toks. Yay.
I suppose we can always find a moment to
squeeze in some mobile media. Um,
however, that also disrupts the industry
because television used to be on a TV
and radio used to be on a radio and
music used to be on a stereo and now
everything competes for attention on
whatever device you happen to have in
front of you. So, this pits the media
companies against each other in a sense
uh in a in a kind of a struggle or
conquest for attention. It's it's
literally television versus streaming
audio versus a game. uh which one is the
consumer going to turn their attention
to and your attention is finite as is
you know everyone knows this is the
scarcest resource is there more to say
about that or have we covered those two
topics fragmentation and uh there's a
lot more to say about that I would
actually frame it differently than you
did because what's what's interesting is
you you could think about for
fragmentation in two ways there's
fragmentation between formats and I mean
between audio and video and gaming and
whatever print Um or you can think about
fragmentation within formats. And what's
interesting is you don't really see a
lot of fragment. Even though the way you
framed it is, you know, that that radio
is competing with TV, you actually don't
really see that. If you look at time
series of time spent by format, what
you'd see is that video, gaming, audio,
they're pretty stable yeartoear. There's
not a lot of there's not a lot of bleed
between them because I think they're
different use cases. is like you're not
usually indifferent between playing a
lean for playing Elden Ring and watching
the Big Bang Theory or whatever. You
know, there there are very different
consumer need states where you see the
fragmentation really happening is within
formats and it's it's largely between
corporate media and creator media. Um so
for instance in video you can see that
right now at least by my math roughly
25% of all video consumption in the US
is social video is you know YouTube, Tik
Tok and reals. Um in music an
interesting thing to watch is that every
year Spotify publishes in their in their
20F in their financial filing they
publish what percentage of stream music
streams come from uh the majors and
Merlin. Merlin is a a distributor of uh
the largest independent distributor and
and what percentage come from outside
the majors in Merlin and that latter
number it goes up every year. So if you
went back like
2017 roughly 90% of streams were the
majors in Merlin and last year it was
like 70%. And so that just goes down
every single year. You think about
gaming and you're seeing the same thing
that a decade ago mobile gaming didn't
exist and now mobile casual gaming is is
half of the industry. So there is a lot
of fragmentation happening to creator
media and you'd say well why is that?
And one there's there's two reasons. One
is obvious and one is less obvious and
really important and insidious and and
worth watching. The first one is just
there's a explosion of supply, right?
more stuff, our attention gets diverted
more places. That's kind of obvious. The
one that's not as obvious is that you're
starting to see evidence, at least you
can infer that the consumer definition
of quality is shifting away from high
production value, right? Cuz what's
really growing across media in video,
what's growing is YouTube. In gaming,
what's growing in is Roblox. In music, a
lot of what's growing is, you know,
functional music, study music, ambient
music, whatever. all of these things
shifting away from the
traditional definition of of quality,
right? Like in TV, what's quality? Like
if you know, if if you ask the people I
used to work with at Turner, they were
to describe an HBO show, right? Like
high budget, well-known showrunner, you
know, famous actor, whatever. And and so
for those people watching this shift of
attention toward YouTube, they're like,
why are people watching that stuff?
That's such crap. you know that's
lowquality stuff it is by your
definition of quality but by inference
if you think about quality not as some
kind of you know independent value
judgment but as revealed preference then
you can see I mean people are telling
you that their definition of quality is
is shifting away from high production
values and so that's really important
when you think about the potential
impact of genai because and we'll get to
this I'm sure but but would you what
you're really setting up for is two
things happening at the same time. One
is that that production values are being
somewhat democratized or will be
democratized by ji at the same time that
consumers
